text: As we look down a gentle rain is falling steadily on a carapace of umbrellas, moving like the scales of some gigantic mythical reptile. The reptile turns out to be a dressed crowd swirling around the entrance to the hall an funnelling slowly into it; the same rain rolling down pos advertising the event they’ve all come to see: the debut concert of David Eli Rapoport, 21 year-old virtuoso violinist.

It is sometimes said that both the shortest and the longest distance in art is that between the very good and the truly great. It may well be that tonight David Eli Rapoport will cross that divide. Those of us who have been privileged to hear his promotional recording are unanimous in declaring the extraordinary playing of this 21-year-old Polish immigrant music from the gods, the voice of possibly the most naturally gifted violinist of his generation... Cars are passing, Festival of Britain flags flying from t building. Pasted across its facade are monochrome publici blow-ups of the lean and Byronic Rapoport and, plastered diagonally across the posters, strip banners reading: “INTERNATIONAL DEBUT PERFORMANCE 7:30 P.M. NOVEMBER 3RD, 1951, with another, smaller strip overplastered: “SOLD OU RETURNS ONLY”. Touts are busy in the crowd, selling outrageously priced tickets to those who have come without one; there’s a pol presence for crowd control - bobbies in glistening rain c - a phalanx of damp press photographers, a St John’s ambulance crew on stand-by. Limousines are delivering DIGNITARIES to the front steps, chauffeurs and assistants shepherding them inside under umbrellas. Big event.

standing at the open stage door, anxiously scanning the w street and checking his watch. After a few moments he goe back inside.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.2 INT. LONDON CONCERT HALL, NIGHT (CONTINUOUS) (A’51) 2 Here there’s every shade of anxiety. The capacity audienc buzzing with restlessness; the orchestra waits in silence having long ago finished tuning up. The BBC RADIO PRESENTER whose voice we’ve been hearing ca seen in the recording booth, holding on to his audience during the delay in the relaxed filibuster style we assoc with Richard Dimbleby at the Coronation [still two years the future].

So great has been the impact of Rapoport’s recording on the world of classical music that one tends to forget how little known his name still is, and that tonight’s concert will be his first on an international stage... BACKSTAGE there’s a frenzy of activity and a sliding scal panic: from the irritation of those mildly inconvenienced the soloist’s lateness to the near hysteria of those most affected, chief among them

Gilbert, the concert’s promoter, is a 56 year-old English gentleman-impresario. He’s standing with his wife, ENID ( and Martin’s fiancée, 21 year-old HELEN. Their son, Marti rejoins them as we watch, shaking his head. All are weari evening dress and all are agitated, though none as much a Gilbert.
He’s had an accident. There’s no other explanation-
We don’t know that.
Martin, I’d like you to phone the hospitals.
I already did, Father. Mr Sanderson's doing it again now. ANGLE ON SANDERSON, the theatre manager, talking urgently the backstage phone.
Has anyone informed the police?
Too soon for that.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018)
How was he this afternoon? Was he all right at rehearsal?
He was fine.
Did he take his violin with him?
He takes it everywhere. He takes it to the loo. p.3 Gilbert shoots his son a disapproving look. Offended by t indelicacy of the comment or by Martin’s attitude?
Gilbert, stop working yourself up into a froth. Perhaps his watch stopped.
A self-winding wristwatch does not stop.
It does if you drop it.
He might’ve got stuck in traffic.
(to Martin) Where did he say was he going after the rehearsal?
He didn’t.
Dovidl does things his own way, Mr Simmonds. He’s probably walking. He likes walking in the rain.
With a Gagliano under his arm? (crossing to stage entrance) Have you seen who’s out there?
Several distinguished-looking men and women waiting.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.4
Peers of the realm, members of Parliament, The Times music critic. Such people are not kept waiting-
He'll be here. This means as much to him as it does to you.
Does it really?
I know-
You don’t know. I’m not talking about money.
I know what you’re talking about.

He could be lying in a gutter somewhere - hurt, dead... ANGE ON AUDITORIUM CLOCK: showing 7:50 BACK TO GILBERT- by now on the edge of tears. The orchestra conductor is looking his way, tapping his watch, tilting his head enquiringly. Time to cancel.
They’1l1 have to be told.
Want me to do it? Gilbert shakes his head. Steps through on to the stage.

My Lords, ladies and gentlemen... (voice quivering) It is with great regret that I have to tell you... the performer you have come to see is unable to be here this evening... (gestures helplessly) Refunds may be claimed at the box office. He hurries offstage, holding back his tears.

head_text.subj: EXT. SIMMONDS HOUSE, HAMPSTEAD, LONDON. DAY

text: TITLE: “35 YEARS LATER”  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.5 A black cab pulls up outside the house and sounds its hor Imposing and costly when it was built in the 1920’s and o by the Simmonds family ever since, the house is now run d and in need of repair and repainting. In the double drive sits a single ten-year-old car: an anomaly in this afflue two-car neighbourhood. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (S’86) 4 The style inside the house is cultured, if a little shabb floor-to-ceiling bookshelves in the drawing room, full of mostly hardback volumes; a baby grand loaded with classic sheet music; somewhat old-fashioned furniture; soft furnishings in muted colours. A suitcase stands in the hall, an overcoat and umbrella draped across it, a briefcase leaning against it.
MARTIN SIMMONDS is now in his mid-fifties, his body slim well kept. HELEN, whose cheek he is kissing in valedictio is still, at the same age, handsome.
(a ritual, this) Take your pills, don’t wear the same shirt twice, sell music.
Kiss Emily for me. The minute the baby’s born, stick it in front of the piano. You can’t start too soon.
‘It’ is a girl, Martin. The scan’s showing a girl. Granddaughter, not grand piano. I'll call you if I’m not asleep.
And if the estimate for the roof comes, let me know straight away.
Why?

I might have to walk home. Save the train fare. The taxi’s horn sounds again.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.6 EXT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (S’86) 5 Martin emerges, coated, carrying suitcase and briefcase, umbrella hooked over his arm. He climbs into the waiting taxi. EXT. GATESHEAD RAILWAY STATION - PLATFORM. DAY (S’86) 6 Exiting the station, Martin is taken aback to find at the barrier the city’s Lord Mayor, CHARLIE FROGGATT (60+), in full regalia, and his driver.
Charlie Froggatt, look at you in your gold chain. Didn’t know this was a civic reception, I’d have worn my ermine underwear. The driver takes Martin’s suitcase. As they walk towards station exit:
(Tyneside accent) Just come from opening a DIY superstore. You’d think they’d do it themselves, wouldn’t you? INT. DAIMLER (TRAVELLING). DAY (S’86) 7
So you're still peddling sheet music, I see.
It’s a living. Libraries and schools buy it.
How long you staying?
Just ‘til Friday.
What are you doing tonight?
Hanging myself, I expect.
How about doing an old friend a favour first?  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.7
This old friend got any pull with the Libraries Committee?
You do one for me, I’1l do one for you.
That’s how the Great War started. (a beat) What’s the favour?
Jury service. (off Martin’s reaction) Competition jury. Tyneside Young Musician of the Year. It’s world famous.
Not the world I live in.
Under-18's who’ve slipped through the music education net - they actually play an instrument. You'd be non-playing Chairman.
You've got to be joking.
I never joke about Tyneside. You'd just be a figurehead. Like me. You're still a name in the music world, man. Your dad knew Paderewski, for Chrissake.
I’m not my father, Charlie. And he didn’t judge Paderewski’s musicianship.
We've got a couple of long-hairs in for that - Tom Noble and Jenny Burrows, you know Jenny. You get the casting vote if they hang.
Forget it, Charlie. I’m here to sell, not buy.
These kids are next year’s customers. (MORE )
Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.8 FROGGATT (cont'd) Chairman of the Libraries Committee happens to be my grandson's girlfriend's uncle.
Talk about connected! EXT. GATESHEAD - DAY (S’86) The limo crossing the Tyne Bridge.

Pick you up at eight. INT. COMMUNITY HALL,GATESHEAD. NIGHT (S’86) A packed hall, an old Steinway grand onstage. Below the stage, seated at a trestle table, the panel of five COMPETITION JUDGES: Martin at their centre, JENNY BURROWS (50) on his left, TOM NOBLE (68) on his right. CHARLIE FROGGATT onstage in his mayoral regalia.
..-and I have every confidence this year’s finalists will maintain the high musical standard for which Tyneside is justly famous.... Shouts of approval from the audience.
(to Martin) Vienna of the north-east.
So without further ado, let competition commence, and may music speak louder than words. He sits down to modest applause.
The first finalist is a 10 YEAR-OLD GIRL playing the Bach Chaconne for clarinet.

Home-made, on council-headed notepaper, the mark sheets a divided into three hand-drawn columns headed “TECHNIQUE”, “INTERPRETATION” and “MUSICALITY”, with a fourth column f totals. The girl’s scores out of ten are uniformly in the four-five range. She scores lowest on interpretation.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.9 - AN 11 YEAR-OLD BOY CELLIST playing Kreisler’s Liebeslei with piano accompaniment. He’s good for his age but in no outstanding. Fives and the odd six. - THE ADJUDICATORS, starting to look glazed. Jenny glanci at her watch. - 16 year-old MARIA KORVINSKY, rippling off Beethoven's Bagatelle in G Minor as though warming up. The audience applause is appropriately mighty. The judges are smiling now, lavishing nines and tens. Gol found in a midden. Barring a further miracle, they’ve got their winner.
(through applause) Can we go home now?
One genius, Jenny. Might be two.
Aye, well, it is Gateshead. FROGGATT has come back onstage.
Our final Young Musician hails from South Shields. He’s 14 years old and has already toured internationally with the Tyneside Youth Orchestra...
(aside) Wales and the Isle of Man.

...So please put your hands together for Peter Stemp. PETER STEMP, a bad acne case, steps onstage and readies himself to play his three-year-old Japanese fiddle. ANGLE ON ELLEN STEMP (40), his proud mother, in the front of the audience. Then Peter does something very odd. Prior to playing his competition piece the boy reaches into his pocket, pulls a block of rosin and ritualistically swipes his bow strin with it - first a broad upward sweep, then a matching downward sweep. Finally, before putting the rosin away an tucking the violin back under his chin-

head_text.subj: HE TOUCHES THE ROSIN TO HIS LIPS

text: 10 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.10 There are some titters from the audience at the gesture.
He isn’t tittering. His reaction is out of all keeping wi what has occurred. It’s a reaction of such shock and emot so sudden and overwhelming, that it has drained the colou from his face.

(to Martin) You all right, man? Martin doesn’t answer. Too stunned to speak. Peter begins to play the second movement of Tartini’s “Devil's Trill” Sonata for solo violin - a difficult piec beyond his skill level, and it shows. But though his musicianship is far from exceptional it’s clear that some at some time, has taught him some old-fashioned Kreisleri slides and a particular treatment of the rosin that very teachers would countenance and no violinist in the histor solo performance would ever exhibit in public... save onl one. ANGLE ON PETER STEMP as he plays, sliding inexpertly... ANGLE ON MARTIN as he listens... INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (A’39) 10 ..-and the playing changes, as the Tartini fades and we h an exuberant Wieniawski violin piece, played by an immeasurably superior violinist. ANGLE ON DAVID ELI RAPOPORT (DOVIDL), aged 9, as he plays sliding with arrogant Kreislerian exuberance...

where 9 YEAR-OLD MARTIN is watching and listening from th hallway. The emotions on his young face: jealousy and resentment. The small drawing room audience is composed of GILBERT(44 here); ENID (39); PROFESSOR CARL FLESCH (58) - Hungarian- soloist and London’s most celebrated pre-war violin teach and ZYGMUNT RAPOPORT (40), Dovidl’s prematurely balding Polish-Jewish father, a Warsaw costume jeweller: not a refugee but with the abandoned worn-down look of one. Dovidl - black hair shiny as jet, legs stick-thin in calf length shorts - is playing with the flashy show-off style a child genius who knows that only time and practice stan between him and his birthright: world-renown as a virtuos Flesch and Gilbert are listening pleasurably, nodding, knowing it too.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p-l1l Martin is two months older than Dovidl. His grey flannel shorts are the right length for London juvenile fashion o the day - the only edge it seems he has on this exotic interloper. Dovidl finishes the piece. He looks up, awaiting requests an encore; spots Martin in the doorway, meets his eye briefly, looks away.
Professor Flesch? What do you think?
Too many flourishes. (to Dovidl) You are not Kreisler, young man.
Kreisler is not Rapoport. A statement of calculated precocity. It brings chuckles.
(to Flesch) You will teach him? He is genius.
I am sent ten geniuses a month, Pan Rapoport. If your son accepts that he has still something to learn, perhaps I can teach him something. You are staying in London?
No, I go back to Warsaw, to my wife and daughters.... If I can find somebody to take David... I leave him here.
Safer. Given the situation in Poland.
(thoughtful) Very much so.
Do you know of Jewish family, Mr Simmonds? I can pay a little...
As it happens I do have a family in mind, Mr Rapoport. It isn’t Jewish, but it is musical, and will cost you nothing. (MORE )

Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.12 GILBERT (cont'd) I can promise you the tenets of your religion would be fully respected, its requirements met in every regard. Gilbert looks across at his wife. He almost certainly has consulted her about this considerable commitment, an autocratic decision typical of the man. ENID gives nothin back - neither consent nor refusal, approval nor disappro Zygmunt is aware how great a commitment this is. It entai among other things, kosher food, Hebrew lessons, Sabbath observance. If he appears to hesitate, consider where he come from. Zygmunt cannot conceive of a Gentile Polish paterfamilias making such an offer.
This is English family?
It is. (a beat) My own son is David’s age. They would share a bedroom.

Outrage on his face. The brilliant interloper is to be admitted to residence, it seems, without any family consultation at all. Zygmunt's eyes are sparkling with tears. He embraces Gilb who stands stiffly to receive the embrace, embarrassed by this un-English gesture, not knowing where to put his han Stepping back, Zygmunt reaches into his pocket and pulls it a velvet-covered ring box. Ceremoniously he presents i his son, the tears overflowing now. The boy opens the box

The inside lid is stamped, in gold leaf lettering: “RAPOP WARSZAWA”. But there is no ring inside. Only a small ambe block of rosin, pristine and gleaming. Everybody smiles as Dovidl removes the rosin and swipes i experimentally along his bow strings: first with a stylis upward flourish, then with a downward. He touches the ros to his lips. Gilbert and Zygmunt applaud. It’s a subtle little ritual whose meaning seems to have eluded ENID, the giving of th box: partly a jeweller’s joke, partly an expression of ho partly a father’s farewell blessing.  11 12 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.13 With his ritualistic stroking of the bow Dovidl has improvised a witty variation: taking the rosin for a run, it were, as though the gift had been a Stradivarius. The on the rosin is for his father, whom he is aware he may n see again. [For Peter Stemp 47 years later it will be a magical ritual entirely without meaning. ] EXT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (A’39) 11 His cardboard suitcase at his feet, Zygmunt is about to l for the bus stop, first leg of his journey back to Poland to what we now know will be invasion, occupation, ghetto death camp - and though he doesn’t know what he’s returni to, Zygmunt seems to intuit it. Hence the passion he puts into his last tearful embrace of the son he may never see again. To Martin and his parents, watching from the doorstep, th is yet another public display of emotion that makes them uncomfortable. It isn’t anti-Semitism, it isn’t coldness; it’s English reserve. INT. HOTEL DINING ROOM, GATESHEAD. DAY (S’86) 12 The day following the competition Martin is lunching with Peter Stemp and his mother, ELLEN (46): a woman of modest means, wearing her best two-piece for the occasion. On the table is The Northern Echo: international and loca news with a Tyneside flavour; several column inches given last night’s music competition: picturing a toothy Maria Korvinsky accepting her prize from Mayor Froggatt.
So what’s this about? You didn’t give Peter the prize, now we’re having this posh lunch. Why?
That wasn’t my decision.
You'd have made him the winner, then? If it was up to you.
The girl’s already there, Mrs Stemp. Peter needs more time... better tuition. (attempting the casual) Who's been teaching him?
He gets lessons in school. I can’t afford fancy teachers.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.14
We could discuss that.
Know a good cheap one, do you?
Several good, none cheap.
In South Shields?
London.
Just have to sell the yacht, then, won't I?
I'll find a way to cover Peter's tuition during his school holidays. And a family in London he can stay with. Ellen looks to Peter. He’s nodding. Wants it.
(indicates newspaper) Why him? Why not what’s-her-face?
Her too.
You think Pete’s that good, then?
He’1ll never be a Heifetz. But he could make a living with an orchestra. Or teaching. (to Peter) Who's been teaching you, Peter?
School.
And who else? You've had a few tips off someone. Peter shrugs.
That thing you do with the rosin....  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018)
That’s for good luck. I can stop.
What’s his name? Maybe I know him. A moment of hesitation, then-
You don’t know him.
I think I might. He used to be a virtuoso. Did he tell you that? Peter smiling now.
I don’t think so.
DSark hair, about my age?
It’s not Pete you want, is it? A harshness has entered her voice. She’s worked bursary, the promise of a management contract - something other than Peter Stemp.

Come on, Pete. We’re going. (to Martin) Thanks for the dinner. p.15 it out. The they’re about Taking Peter by the hand, she pulls him to his feet. They leave the dining room without looking back. 13 INT. MARTIN’S HOTEL ROOM, GATESHEAD. NIGHT (S’86) 13 Martin is perched on his bed, on the phone to Helen.

(to phone) What are they calling it? Sorry, her. (winces ) Lovely name. Kiss little Cressida for me, I'll see her Sunday. (a pause) Helen...? I think I might have found him. There’s no response. No request to identify the silence. “him”. Just  14 15 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.16
Did you hear what I said? INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (SIMULTANEOUS) (S’86) 14 Helen’s in bed, her book set aside to take Martin’s call.

(to phone, tonelessly) I heard. Goodnight, Martin. INT. MARTIN’S BEDROOM, SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (A’39) 15 This is the first time Martin and Dovidl have been left a together. Dovidl is in the bedroom doorway with his cheap suitcase between his feet, waiting to be invited in.
(heavily accented) I sleep here, yes?
No. I don’t want you in my room. I like being on my own.
Is not your choose.

Wrong, clever. It is my “choose”. I have to say if it’s all right and if it isn’t you go back to Poland, and the Germans are going to invade Poland. You’1l have to wear a yellow star and get bashed up by brownshirts.
What is “bashed up”, please? A pause.
You better not snore, that’s all.
What is snore? Martin does the sound for him. Dovidl pulls a small noteb and pencil from his pocket and records the word.
If I snore I snore in tune. I am musician. You play?  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.17
Piano, a bit.
Is good for accompanist. Chess?
A bit.
(grins) Everything for you is bit. I am genius. I help you, you will be bit genius.
Bet I could get you down. Dovidl’s pencil gets busy a second time. Another new word

What is “get down”, please? Martin jumps him. Operative definition. The boys wrestle, grunting and snorting. But eventually i the wiry Dovidl who wrestles Martin to the ground and sit on his chest, pinning his arms.
Also fight a bit.
(terminal frustration) Bloody foreigner! You can’t even talk proper English!
You speak Polish? Russian? Yiddish? German? Hebrew?
I don’t have to. I’m not one of your lot.
What is “lot”?
Foreigners. We’re in England, stupid. Dovidl climbs off him, retrieves his notebook; wags it.
Wait six months.  16 17 18 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.18
What’s your name, anyway?
Dovid Eli Rapoport. My family call me Dovidl. You?
Martin L. Simmonds.
I call you Mottl. INT. GATESHEAD HOTEL BEDROOM. MORNING (S’86) 16 Martin is eating a room-service breakfast at a small whee table when there’s a tentative knock at the door. He open to:
Peter. Where’s your mother? He checks the corridor. No Ellen. Came alone.

I‘1l take you to him. EXT. GATESHEAD. DAY (S’86) 17 They've come by taxi to an underpass entrance: a pedestri tunnel beneath a busy urban road. EXT/INT. SUBWAY. DAY (S’86) 18 As Martin and Peter descend the steps we’1ll hear a dista violin playing - with only moderate competence - The Roll Stones’ “Paint it Black”. Martin’s face falls. Whoever is playing, it isn’t Dovidl. As they get closer, so does the music. A turn in the tunn reveals...

The busker is BILLY, an unkempt grizzly-bearded man in hi seventies, wearing a stained raincoat, football socks and dirty plimsolls. He’s playing on a cheap fiddle - complet with unwanted echoes off the tiled walls. On the floor at feet, among the crisp packets and banana skins, is his ca dotted with a handful of low-value coins.  19 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.19 Though he’d known from the first bow-stroke that this cou not be Dovidl, Martin wilts with disappointment. Billy nods an acknowledgement at Peter but barely glances Martin as he finishes the piece with a flourish of poorly executed Kreisleresque slides. Then out comes the rosin, followed by that ritualistic up-and-down stroking of the bowstrings with which we’re becoming familiar, and the valedictory kiss to the rosin, a magical ritual as meaningless to Billy as it is to Peter.
This is Mr Simmonds, Billy. He's gonna pay for me to have lessons. In London.
(London accent) What did I tell you? (to Martin) Told him he’d get discovered.
He says you’ve been helping him.
(laughs) Showed him a couple of things.
Where did you learn to play?
Taught meself. Martin takes out his wallet. Extracts a fiver, drops it i the hat.
That's very kind of you, sir.
Teach yourself those Kreisler slides, did you, Billy? Billy's face sets.
Who wants to know?
Your best customer. INT. CAFE, GATESHEAD. DAY (S’86) 19 Billy, Peter and Martin are drinking thick tea from thick white mugs at a formica-topped table.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.20
He never told me his name. It was years ago.
Where did you meet him?
London. I used to work the cinema queues up west - when they had cinema queues. I wasn’t bad then-
What year?
(thinks ) High Noon. When was that?
452, I think. Go on.

So I’m outside the Odeon, yeah, playing the theme music - you know, from the film - and this cheeky little bugger comes up, tells me I could do with some lessons. ‘Oh, yeah,’ I says. ‘Who from?’ ‘I don’t normally give lessons,’ he says, only he’s saving up for this trip he wants to go on, so how much can I afford to pay him? I told him to get knotted. Don’t even know he can play, do I?
I assume he demonstrated.

Takes me violin right out me hand. You never heard nothing like it in your life. Magic. Like something off the wireless. (shakes his head in wonder) Crowd starts chucking half crowns, ten-bob notes. I give him half. Fair's fair, right?
What did he look like?
Like he could do with a square meal.  20 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.21
When was the last time you saw him?
Important, is it? Martin deposits another fiver on the sticky table top.
He give me a few lessons. Twice a week for a bit. One day he didn’t turn up. Never saw him again. Must’ve gone on his trip.
Did he say where?
Didn’t make much sense, like, but that’s why I remember it. Martin waits. Billy waits. Another fiver goes down.

Said he was going home to play for the Ashes. That’s cricket, innit? When England plays Australia. (Martin nods) Didn’t make sense ‘cos he didn’t sound like an Aussie. ‘Who’re you, then?’ I says. ‘Don bleeding Bradman?’
His exact words? Billy’s brow furrows with the effort of recall.
Something about a song. Going home - to play a song. (a beat) For the ashes.

This doesn’t mean anything to us but it contains a world meaning for Martin. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (A’39) 20 A family dinner is being eaten in silence as everybody listens to the evening news on the wireless. It’s a Frida night and for Dovidl’s benefit there are Sabbath candles the table and a loaf of chala wrapped in a white cloth.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.22 We should note that Dovidl’s dinner plate contains differ food from the others’, mostly vegetables. The news is all about the German Blitzkrieg of Poland: th bombing of Warsaw, the collapse of the Polish army. The Phoney War is a few days old. Dovidl’'s face reflects his struggle to contain his emoti He’s learning to be English.
I’m sure your family will be all right, David.
Have you written home, David?
I am writing letter.
Good lad.
You permit I make more letter now?
Permission granted, old chap. As Dovidl prepares to leave the table-
He hasn’t finished his dinner.
Special dispensation. Go and finish your letter, David. Dovidl slides off his seat and leaves the room.
It’s not fair.
What isn’t?
All this. No bacon allowed in the house, no milk puddings, special food for the genius, and he doesn’t even have to eat it.
If you'd like to take over preparing David’s food you may have a say in whether he eats it.  21 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.23
And he’s a liar. He stopped writing two weeks ago.
It isn’t very nice, Martin, to tell tales on a friend.
My friends don’t wet the bed. The Simmonds adults exchange a look.
Considering the position his family is in, I'd say wetting the bed is the least we can expect from him.
(to Martin) Why don’t you go and see if you can cheer him up.
Didn’t look all that down to me.
That’s a wicked thing to say! Go to your room!

Not my room, is it. He goes. INT. LANDING/THE BOYS’ BEDROOM. NIGHT (A’39) 21 Through the partly open door we catch Dovidl looking at a photograph and crying. It’s a sepia studio portrait of th Rapoport family taken in Warsaw in 1937: Dovidl’s father mother standing side by side; in front of them, Dovidl ag seven between his two sisters: Pessia (9) and Malkeh (5). Pessia has her arm around Dovidl’s shoulders; Dovidl’s ar around Malkeh’s. All five are solemn and unsmiling, in th portrait style of the time. As Martin enters Dovidl slides the photo under his pillow Martin doesn’t see it. Trying to recover his equilibrium, Dovidl blows his nose.
I have cold. A sudden unexpected shaft of compassion pierces Martin's juvenile soul.  22 23 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.24
They'll be all right. We’1ll smash the Jerries up for you. No-one stands up to the British Army.
You are child.
Play you a game of chess if you want.
Chess with you takes my mind two minutes.

(a grin) Three. I feel lucky. EXT. HAMPSTEAD. DAY (A‘39) 22 The two boys are freewheeling down a hill on their bikes, playing “chicken”. Martin is the first to swerve - avoiding a horse-drawn mi float. Dovidl sails on, misses the float by inches, and i passing swipes a pint. Riding no-hands, he pierces the to with his finger while still on the move and swigs from th bottle. It’s Martin who gets nabbed by the milkman - momentarily caught by his coat - before he breaks away and pedals mad down the hill after Dovidl, who has disappeared from view

Thieving little bleeders! EXT. HAMPSTEAD HEATH. DAY (A’39) 23 Martin finds Dovidl waiting in their private spot on the Heath: beneath a large tree, overlooking the Ponds. Eatin Kit Kat [N.B. Wartime issue: blue wrapper, dark chocolate price 3d]. Grinning in triumph, Dovidl offers Martin a finger of Kit Kat.
Thought you said these weren’t kosher.
You rabbi now?  24 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.25
Where'd you get it?
Your pocket. He proffers the milk bottle. Martin takes a swig.

We make good team, yes? Embarrassed by Dovidl’s open acknowledgement of what in a London boy's world should remain implicit, Martin sprays with milk. Dovidl responds by jumping on him playfully. T wrestle standing up for a few moments, then both boys ste back to face one another and go by tacit agreement into t slow motion boxers routine. This consists of each delivering in turn a slo-mo punch w the other has the option either to dodge in slow motion o receive as a simulated blow, rocking back under the prete impact with appropriate facial grimaces. INT. HALLWAY, PROFESSOR FLESCH’S STUDIO. DAY (WINTER 1940 Dovidl has come for his violin lesson, accompanied by GILBERT. On the landing outside Flesch’s studio they meet JOZEF WECHSLER (18) about to descend. He’s carrying a ver old violin case, housing the virtuoso’s badge of office: very old violin.
Professor Flesch isn’t here. I’ve been waiting an hour.
Do you know where he is?
Back in Hungary, probably. He thinks the Waffen SS are coming over London Bridge. His glance, finding Dovidl, takes in his leatherette-cove violin case, doubtless containing a cheap violin.
(to Gilbert, with an inclination of the head) Jozef Wechsler. Of Warsaw. You will have heard of me.

Gilbert Simmonds. I believe Professor Flesch has mentioned you.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.26 Dovidl’s look is one of undisguised envy. Wechsler, alrea an international name at eighteen and with the arrogance young god, is who he wants to be - preferably tomorrow.
(to Jozef) Dovid Eli Rapoport. Also of Warsaw. Professor Flesch has spoken of you to me also.
He hasn’t spoken of you. (to Gilbert) Your boy will need to find a new teacher. You know Dr Steiner of Leipzig?
I know of him.
He has played Mozart with Einstein. He is in London now.
I learn physics, I go Einstein.
Mr Wechsler isn’t recommending Einstein as a violin teacher, David.
I practise alone.
And from whom will you learn humility?
Not from you. With a sad shake of the head, Jozef leaves. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (W’40) 25 Having returned home, Gilbert and Dovidl enter the living room to find Martin practising at the piano.
(to Dovidl) Actually, Steiner’s not a bad idea.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.27
I do not need teacher. Only to practise.
Who will make sure you don’t skip the tricky bits when your fingers are hurting? Martin swings around on the piano stool.
How about me?
Hah. Boy of ten.
Older than you.
Fifty-five days older... (calculating) .»»-one point five-one percent. One- and-six out of a fiver. Small change.
That’s six Kit Kats-
Boys! Please. It’s a very mature undertaking.
I’m more mature than he is.
Hah. This initiates another ritual. Momentarily forgetting his father’s presence, Martin jumps off the stool and launche into the slow motion boxers routine.
Boys, if you’ve finished demonstrating your maturity - They stop.

(to Martin) Suppose some difficulty were to arise that I needed to know about, and your friend asked you to keep it from me. Wouldn’t that be a conflict of loyalties?  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.28
My loyalty’s to you, Father. Gilbert puts his arms around both boys’ shoulders.

We'll give it a go. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (S’86) 26 Returning from Gateshead, Martin lugs his suitcase into t house. He finds Helen in the living room, marking school essays and too absorbed to hear him enter. He crosses to kisses the nape of her neck.
I might've been a burglar.
With his own key?
Locksmith by trade. How's Emily?
Blooming.
And little Isolde? What was it?
Cressida. Can’t read, write or play a note but she knows her name. You’1l see her tomorrow. A pause. Silence.
How was your trip?
I made back the train fare. A longer pause.
So? What did you find?
Dovidl was still in London in 1952.
There’s a hot trail for you.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.29
It means whatever his reason for not turning up, it wasn’t because he was dead. We never knew that for sure before.
Just because he was alive thirty- odd years ago doesn’t mean he is now.
He’s our age. Why wouldn’t he be?
This going to be your new hobby, Martin? Finding David after half a lifetime so he can spit in your eye again?
If you'd lost a brother-
(cutting in) He wasn’t your brother.
He felt like a brother.
And what do I feel like?
What?
To you.
This isn’t a competition.
Everything's a competition. Read your Darwin.
Helen, I’m tired, I’m hungry, I need a bath and I don’t want to have this conversation.
Then we’ll have it later, when you're fed and rested.
No, you can do it solo - both parts. I’1l be the audience.
27 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.30 He turns to leave.
Where did he go in 1952?
I thought you weren’t interested.
(shrugs) Historical curiosity.

Poland. He went to Poland. He goes out and closes the door behind him. Helen remains her chair but does not resume her marking. EXT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. EARLY EVENING (A’40) 26A Blast tape on the windows of houses. A car passes with it headlights shaded. A military lorry drops Gilbert at the house. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. EARLY EVENING (CONTINUOUS) (A’40) 27 Same room as Scenes 25 and 26, same piano, but with the furnishings of the period; complete with taped windows an not-yet-drawn blackout curtains. No lights are on and the room is gloomy. Barely able to see his music, Martin is at the piano, accompanying Dovidl; playing chords to which Dovidl is practising his staccato technique. Suddenly Dovidl stops playing. Martin carries on for a mo or two before he registers this. Then he, too, stops; swi on the stool to face Dovidl.
I didn’t say you could stop.
My neck is hurting. [N.B. Dovidl’s English is already far less heavily accent
It’s supposed to. He swivels back to the keyboard.
I have done enough.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.31 Martin swivels back to Dovidl.
I decide when you’ve done enough. Dovidl picks up his violin case.
I’1l tell him, Dov. I mean it.
Tittle-tattle.
Baby. Gilbert enters the room, wearing an ARP armband (Air Raid Precaution - a warden).
Sorry to interrupt, boys. He crosses to the window, closes the blackout curtains, switches on the light.
Now you can see what you're doing. Silence from the boys.
How are your Hebrew lessons going David? Happy with Mr Rosenthal’s teaching? I know you were getting along well with Mr. Cohen.
(proudly) He joined up. R.A.F.
Yes, I know. Important that you keep on with your religious studies. I promised your father. As Gilbert turns away;
They do not say Hebrew words same as in Poland, Mr. Simmonds
Then... He’s about to recommend that Dovidl learn the British sty of pronunciation, but in that instant realises that the European style may soon cease to exist.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.31A
Say them the way you were taught in Poland.
Thank you, Mr Simmonds.
(to Martin) How’s the violin coming along? Martin exchanges a look with Dovidl. If he’s going to rat out, this is the moment. It’s a long moment.  28 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.32
All right.
What’s he working on?
Staccato, Mr Simmonds.
Good, good. (indicating window) Well, you may as well keep at it till Herr Hitler's Gétterdammerung starts up. He goes out.
You owe me one.
How you make that out?
I could've told him. I didn’t.

View from the piano stool. Here is standing view: I know you should tell him. I know you did not. He does not know it. But as Martin begins to play THE AIR RAID SIREN starts up moment later the electricity fails and the lights go off. EXT. AIR RAID SHELTER ENTRANCE. SAME NIGHT (A’40) 28 The promised Gétterdammerung. Bombs falling, the flash of incendiaries, searchlights and tracer illuminating the sk Gilbert, Enid, Martin and Dovidl are descending the steps into the shelter: Enid and Martin lugging blankets, therm flasks, sandwiches; Dovidl carrying only his violin case. Dovidl stops to look up at the light show in the sky.
You want to get killed?
Is not my destiny. It would have been like this - Warsaw would have been like this.  29 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.33
Couldn’t have been worse. Come on. Dovidl doesn’t move.
Look, if we’re okay they probably are too. Your mum and dad, your sisters. They’d have had the sense to go to the shelters.
Look how beautiful it is.
It’s not art, Dovidl. It’s bloody life and death.
So is art. A lone figure approaches, also heading for shelter: JOZEF WECHSLER (now nearly 20), carrying only his cased violin. Martin nudges Dovidl. Look who it is.
(to Martin) So what? You want plaque? “Jozef Wechsler cowered here, 1940."? Jozef passes without acknowledging them.
(to Jozef: attempting inclusiveness) Hampstead Shelter Orchestra.

What instrument do you play? Having delivered this majestic put-down, Wechsler surges regally past a Dovidl too stunned to reply. INT. AIR RAID SHELTER. NIGHT (A’40) 29 Jozef has settled among the crowd, camped as far as possi from the Simmondses. As Martin, Gilbert and Enid busy themselves spreading blankets and pillows, Dovidl removes his modest little vi from its case. He strokes the bowstrings with his block o Warsaw rosin, kisses the rosin, then casually begins to p a jaunty classical piece.  30 31 Yellow - SoN D9.3 (11/15/2018) p.34-34A Gilbert’s face displays pride; Jozef is trying to show am indifference. But it seems there’s only so much a genius stand. Unable to resist, Jozef at last takes up his own venerable instrument and joins in, merging seamlessly wit Dovidl. There is no apparent disparity in skill between t two performers and what at first seems a co-operative exercise soon grows savagely competitive- -as Jozef switches suddenly to a more demanding piece- -and Dovidl matches him effortlessly, bar for bar, finess for finesse- -and Dovidl switches to a notoriously tricky Paganini cap -and Jozef meets the challenge unerringly. Both of them smiling. Jozef thinking: ‘This kid’s not half bad.’ EXT WARSAW AIRPORT. DAY (S’86) 30 A British Airways plane is about to land... ...-Martin exits the terminal and climbs into a taxi EXT. WARSAW. DAY (S’86) 31 Martin’s taxi on its way from the airport to the city cen

This is a Warsaw far removed from the pre-war city Dovidl would have known as a boy but not much different from the he visited in 1953, except that Solidarnosc flags and hoardings proliferate along the roadside and on the facad of buildings. The TAXI DRIVER is a man in his seventies. The car radio playing softly in the background.
Does Warsaw have a Musicians’ Union?
No English.
Un-i-on. Music?
Nie rozumiem. The driver turns up the volume on his radio.  Yellow - SoN D9.3 (11/15/2018) p.34-340A

The search isn’t going to be as easy as he thought.  32 Yellow - SoN D9.3 (11/15/2018) p.35 EXT. HAMPSTEAD STREET. DAY (S’43) 32 More than two years after the Blitz, London has taken an unexpected overnight pasting from the Luftwaffe. The boys standing on the rim of a smoking bombsite, holding their bikes, peering into the rubble.
Thought we had the Blitz two years ago.

This is a footnote. (a beat) Look, there’s a body. ANGLE - an arm protruding from behind a half-demolished w  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.36 Martin follows Dovidl as he picks his way over the rubble towards it. He stoops to retrieve something shiny. He hol it up for Martin to see. A silver bracelet.

Has it got a name on it? Dovidl shakes his head. Pockets the bracelet. He moves out of sight behind the wall, which has a carpet staircase still intact against it. Martin pulls a Kit Kat bar from his pocket; unwraps it an takes a bite, surveying the wreckage as he munches. A mom or two passes, then Dovidl reappears, a purse in his hand
(horrified) What are you doing!?
It’s Mrs Harris. She’s on my paper round. The face is gone but I recognise the purse. He opens the purse, and with a triumphant yell extracts a pound note.
Treasure of the Mummy’s Tomb!
(appalled) Do you know what you get for robbing the dead?
Pound notes.
A firing squad. Dovidl makes his way over to where Martin is standing and passes him without pausing, flapping the banknote.
Eighty Kit Kats, Mott.
(calling after him) It isn’t yours!

I don’t mind sharing. Reaching the street, he mounts his bike and pedals away.  33 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.37 EXT. HAMPSTEAD HEATH. DAY (LATER) (S’43) 33 They've repaired to their private spot on the Heath to sm cigarettes and drink brown ale from bottles. Dovidl is setting out on the grass an array of raunchy playing card each depicting a nude woman in a saucy pose.
Who do you fancy? The ace of clubs has the best tits, the four of diamonds is the best bum.
Your bar mitzvah's in ten days, Dov. You’re supposed to be a man. Looking at pictures of naked women doesn’t make you a man.
Neither does watching Shirley Smith undress through binoculars.
That was a scientific experiment.
In what? Team wanking? Anyway, you don’t look like a man.
Neither do you.
More than you.
Bollocks.
That too.
Being a man doesn’t mean that, does it?
What are you now, a Talmud scholar? What does it mean, O wise one?
Among other things, respecting the dead.
Why? Because they’re dead? Out of interest, are they supposed to know they’re being respected?  34 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.38
Their loved ones know.
Mrs Harris didn’t have any loved ones. No-one’s going to miss her. Mind you, she made good fishcakes. I’ll miss her fishcakes.
(truly appalled) Is that all she meant to you?
What else?

This was a human person, Dov. She probably went to bed last night planning to... I don’t know, make fishcakes, and she ends up dead in the rubble of her house. Don’t you feel anything? Dovidl turns to look at him.
Do you know how many people died last night, Mottl? I don’t just mean in London. Across Occupied Europe. Shot, bayonetted, blown up, starved, burnt alive, hung-
That’s not the point.

Tens of thousands. And no-one even knows their names. So tell me, little man from NW3, which ones do I have to “feel” for? All of them or just the ones I trip over the morning after? INT. SYNAGOGUE. DAY (S’43) 34

Sitting together at the back, wearing skullcaps for respe but as out of place as Hottentots at a Greek wedding. The attracting curious looks from the regular congregation (t being the synagogue Dovidl regularly attends), none of wh have seen them here before. CAMERA FINDS ENID, alone in the women’s section, even mor isolated.  35 36 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.39
Wearing a dark blue suit and embroidered silk kippah, the mitzvah boy is at the bimah, fluently reciting his Hebrew Torah portion.
(...)Lay yisyatzev ish bifneychem: pakhd’khem umayraakhem yiten Adonay Elaykhekhem al penay khol hooretz asher tidrekhi vah, kaasher diber lokhem. The Torah is covered.
Borikh atoh Adonay, Elayheyni melekh hoaylom, asher nosan loni tayras emes v’khayei aylom nota b’saykheni. Borikh ato Adonai nayseyn hatayroh.
(---) No man shall stand up to you: the LORD your God will put the dread and the fear of you over the whole land in which you set foot, as He promised you.
We praise You, Eternal God, Sovereign of the Universe: You have given us a Torah of truth, implanting within us eternal life. We praise You, O God, Giver of the Torah.

Shekoyach! May your force grow! EXT. FRYDERYK CHOPIN UNIVERSITY OF MUSIC. DAY (S’86) 35 A ‘modern’ concrete structure in central Warsaw, built in sixties. INT. FRYDERYK CHOPIN UNIVERSITY OF MUSIC. DAY (S’86) 36 Photographs of prominent Polish musicians decorate the wa several violinists among them. Away down the corridor a chamber orchestra can be heard practising. Martin arrives at the door to an administrative office. Inside he finds a middle-aged female RECEPTIONIST.
Dobry dzien, Pani. No response. Obviously doesn’t speak her own language.
Do you speak English? The receptionist tilts her head. A tentative yes, possibl

I'm looking for a violinist - David Eli Rapoport. He isn’t one of your graduates but he might have performed here in the ‘fifties... INT. ARCHIVE, F. CHOPIN UNIVERSITY OF MUSIC. DAY (S’86) 3 A secretary produces a heavy bound volume and plops it do in front of Martin. INSERT LIST OF NAMES as Martin scans it. Hundreds of names and dates of graduation. Many names end in -SKI and -ISCZ. Radivicz... Rakowicz... Razinsky. No Rapoports.
These are all graduates of the school. Isn’t there a record of musicians who've played here?
For record store you go Srédmiescie.
I don’t mean a recording. A written record. He taps the book sharply in demonstration. The secretary responds by closing the book with a snap. His tap seen as violation.
Although he didn’t expect instant success, his expression shows his disappointment. He realizes it’s a hopeless tas without at least a working knowledge of Polish.

Thank you. Dziekuje Ci. He turns and leaves. INT./EXT. BAILEY’S OF BROADWICK STREET. NIGHT (S’43) 37 Gilbert arrives by taxi with the two boys outside one of London’s most venerable musical instrument sellers. INT. BAILEY’S. NIGHT (S’43) 38 He is greeted warmly by ADRIAN BAILEY (57) as a valued customer of long standing. Dismissing Martin with a glanc Bailey contemplates Dovidl appraisingly.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.41
How old is the boy ?
The boy’s thirteen.
A man, Mr Bailey - in David's culture. Taking Dovidl’s left hand in both his own, Bailey flexes Dovidl’s fingers.
Good fingers. (to Gilbert) Do you have a luthier in mind?
Nothing outrageously expensive, Mr Bailey. But a good one.

Let’s leave the Strads to the millionaires. I have something special for him. Bailey smiles, then disappears into a back room. Martin is scowling. A few moments of awkward silence pass before Bailey retur holding a worn violin case and a bow. He sets the case do and extracts the instrument. At the sight of it Dovidl’s eyes gleam with avarice.
This is a Nicolo Gagliano filio. He hands bow and violin to Dovidl, who receives them with reverence due a holy relic.
The son of Alessandro Gagliano made this instrument in 1735, the year of his father’s death. Many think it was a tribute violin. (to Dovidl) And your father-
Foster father.  39 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.42 Gilbert glares at his son.
-..-does not have to be Rothschild to afford it.
Happy bar mitzvah, David.
Thank you, sir.

Where’s mine? Forced laughter from the two men. If Gilbert is aware how cruel he’s being to his natural son he isn’t showing it. But Dovidl is too distracted to spare a thought for Marti He’s examining the instrument with a lustful eye. Taking the ring box from his pocket, he extracts his bloc rosin, swipes the bowstrings with it - once up, once down then kisses the rosin. Bailey shoots Gilbert an enquiring look but no explanation is offered. Dovidl has tucked the Gagliano under his chin and is test its range and resonance, playing short snatches of music various styles and in rapid succession. A smile of pleasure extends across Bailey’s face.

(to Gilbert) See how she responds. It will be a happy marriage. INT. WARSAW HOTEL ROOM. NIGHT (S’86) 39 Martin is working the Warsaw phone book, calling any poss source he can think of. It’s another hopeless task, limit by his rudimentary Polish, the poor English of his interlocutors and scratchy phone connections.
(to phone) Rapoport. R-A-P-O-P-O-R-T. He would have been here from about the early 1950’s. I don’t know how long- (interrupted) Of course. Thank you anyway, Pani.

head_text.subj: SAME SCENE, PERHAPS AN HOUR LATER

text: Another phone call.  40 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.43

(to phone, frustrated) No, I’m asking for your enquiry rates... (listens) Money. Pieniadze. Do you charge by the assignment or by the hour? (listens in frustration) I’m sorry to have troubled you. I’m afraid I need someone who speaks fluent English. Fluent Polish comes down the line.

(to himself) Q.E.D. Putting down the phone, he crosses to the window and stan looking out at the city. A train passing in the near distance triggers a memory... INT. LONDON RAILWAY TERMINUS. DAY (W’47) 40 GILBERT descends from the boat train with an ENSEMBLE OF MUSICIANS, their luggage and instrument cases plastered w Polish and other European travel stickers. Returning from two-week cultural tour of post-war Russian-occupied Polan Waiting at the platform entrance are MARTIN and DOVIDL, b now seventeen. Martin is still a pink-faced adolescent; Dovidl, already man-shaped, has a pronounced beard shadow the stricken, grief-rimmed eyes of an unconfirmed orphan. Those eyes searching Gilbert for news.
I’m sorry, David. I tried very hard, you must believe me.
Are you sure you went to the right address? Dzielna 21?
Your apartment - the tenement your family lived in... no longer exists, I’m afraid. Dovidl’s face. Gilbert places a sympathetic hand on his shoulder.

Not the worst news, David. Definitely not the worst. (to Martin) Can you manage the cases?  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.44 ANGLE ON WARSAW STICKER ON SUITCASE as Martin lifts it. 41 INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (W’47) Al Same day. At dinner: Gilbert, Enid, Martin, Dovidl.
(to Enid) David's family definitely survived the Ghetto. We know that much. They were deported before the Uprising in ‘43.
Deported where? A pause. He hates even the word.
Treblinka. Dovidl has already been told this but the terrible name shocks him anew.
They're dead, Mrs Simmonds.

No, David! That is not something we May assume. There was a mass revolt. Hundreds escaped. Hundreds. I will not give up the search and you must not give up hope. There are any number of places they could be - one of the DP camps, Russia, possibly-
Why did you take Jozef Wechsler to Poland and not me? I play as well as he does.
You’re not ready yet.
I could've looked for myself. I speak Polish.
So does Jozef, and what it got him was the worst news - confirmed by the Polish authorities. The other reason I didn’t take you is that I’m responsible for you in a way I am not for Jozef. (MORE )
Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.45 GILBERT (cont'd) You're both Polish citizens - something we must rectify, by the way. They could have kept you there. Witness what happened to poor Jozef.
What happened to him?

His entire family’s gone. The Poles have kept him. (a beat) In an asylum. 42 INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (SAME EVENING) (W’47) 42 A search is underway for Dovidl. Gilbert comes in from th garden, his face fretted with concern.
He’s not in the shed. Did he say anything?
Just said he wanted to be alone. (a beat) He took his violin.
Is he likely to do anything silly?
Yes, Mother. Run away and join a band.
For God's sake, Martin! His entire family’s almost certainly been wiped out! Show some compassion.
You mean the way he would, in my position?
I don’t doubt it for a moment. He’s been like a brother to you.
And a son to you.  43 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.46
If there’s some secret place you boys have I’ve no need to know where it is. Just go there and find him. Martin goes out without a word.
David isn’t the suicidal type.

All artists are the suicidal type. EXT. HAMPSTEAD HEATH. NIGHT (SAME NIGHT) (W’47) 43 We find Martin and Dovidl sitting under a tree in their private place on the margin of Hampstead Ponds: Martin smoking a cigarette, Dovidl a pipe. The sepia family portrait we saw in Scene 21 is lying bes Dovidl on the grass. The Gagliano, out of its case, hangs bizarrely from a branch by the loose end of one its strin
My father thinks you’ve topped yourself. Dovidl smiles.
Against my religion.
Prodigal quasi-son wanted home, Dov.
Goody. Quasi-fatted calf for din- dins.
You really are a cold bastard, you know that? He flops down beside his friend.

(indicating the violin) It’s that thing I’m killing: the varnished tyrant. I’m glad you came. Murder needs witnesses. Noticing the photograph, Martin picks it up and studies i  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.47
(of the photo) Why haven’t I seen this?
It’s how I’ve kept them safe. Hiding them. From everyone.
I’m not everyone. Martin picks it up, studies it.
Which one’s Malkeh? Dovidl points.
She's five there. Pessia was nine.
What was it like? That life?

Still Life with Jews. Boys playing football, old men praying, ritual baths for the women. Malkeh was too young for that so she would stay home - I’d play her a lullaby at bedtime. My father would wander the streets - every day, Mottl, imagine - every evening except the sabbath - selling his jewellery, pieces he made while the rest of us were asleep. Just so we could eat. Sometimes we didn’t... Emotion catches him by the throat.
It’s only presumption of death. Why your rabbi won’t let you say kiddish, right? Dovidl manages a smile.
Kiddush is the blessing over wine. I can still say that. This is the Kaddish: (closes his eyes) (MORE )
Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.48 DOVIDL (cont'd) Yisgadal v’yisqadash sh’mai rabah...
Don’t, Dov. Not if you’re not supposed to.
Do you think I’d go mad if I knew for certain? Strip off and run naked through the streets like Wechsler, waving my violin. “Israelites to your bows! The Philistines are upon us!”
I don’t think he did that.
Can’t see it working in Hampstead.
Wechsler started out half barmy.
And I’m not?
You’ve got me.
A stabilising influence.
Ordinary and boring.
Good for leaning on. Like this tree.
Nice to know I’m good for something.
Stop fishing for compliments, Mottl. This is my life crisis, not yours.
Hey, how about a joint life crisis? Joint suicide note. We don’t have to do it, just drive my father nuts. Dovidl laughs.  44 45 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.49
Do you think he'll ever recover?
Who?

Wechsler. Will he stay mad for ever, do you think? What do they do to lunatics in Poland, I wonder? Ice cold baths? Heap ashes on your head? It’s a place of ashes, Mottl.
